awd_titl_txt: CRII: SHF: Supporting Domain-Specific Inquiry with Rule-Based Modeling
awd_abstract_narration:
Writing computer simulations of processes such as ecologies, economic models, social dynamics, government procedures, and biological regulation, can lead to greater understanding of these systems for novices and experts alive. Rule-based modeling allows novice programmers to specify and run these simulations without training in probability theory or traditional programming languages. The proposed work extends a rule-based modeling language to support self-directed learning of the language and domain-specific inquiry about the models. In the long term, this work will enable cross-communication between experts in different domains and will broaden participation in systems thinking skills applicable across STEM disciplines.

The underlying rule-based language, Ceptre, is based on a fragment of linear logic, enabling compositional reasoning about programs. The proposed work entails developing a structure editor for Ceptre designed to support the key principles of discoverability, supporting new users to learn the language in a self-directed manner, and correctness-by-construction, or the prevention of syntax errors through an editing interface that maps between only meaningful edit states. This part of the project will be rigorously validated with formal proofs of soundness and completeness of the editing interface with respect to the underlying language. The domain-specific inquiry component of the project will be accomplished by developing a language and algorithms to support queries and filters on simulation states, "Why" questions about program traces, statistical analysis on sets of traces, and other means of understanding the emergent behavior of simulations. These tools will be evaluated through user studies on populations of domain experts and programming novices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to discover technological and design principles for tools that help people create computer simulations of systems. Our approach involves developing a structure editor for a rule-based modeling language as well as analysis and debugging functionality appropriate to audiences with no to little programming background. Our long-term impact goals include education in computational thinking and facilitating cross-disciplinary communication across fields as disparate as economics, biology, social science, and game design.


Project Activity Summary

Over the lifetime of the project, we designed and implemented the Ceptre Editor, then conducted a small human subjects study to evaluate its usability and support for learning accurate mental models of systems, the results of which we presented at the VL/HCC conference. We iterated our software design based on this study data, including a user interface redesign and new program features. We also carried out an accessibility audit and learned that Ceptre is amenable to use with popular accessibility tools for disabled programmers, specifically voice programming tools and screen readers, support for which we integrated into the software prototype with minimal effort. In addition, we developed a domain-specific formalism for using Ceptre to author puzzle games that take place on a two-dimensional grid, establishing the language’s amenability to building domain-specific formalisms on top of it. Finally, we synthesized and distilled our theoretical model of the Ceptre language into a formalism that we have shown to be replicable in many software contexts and comprehensible by people without a background in formal logic. We have documented and published these findings both in scientific papers and as a public website. 


Intellectual Merit

This project contributes novel results to programming language design, human-computer interaction, and STEM education. New scientific findings generated by this project include:

  • Ceptre’s linear logic-based programming model posed no obstacles to use or understanding for study participants without training in formal logic, when scaffolded with a structure editing tool;

  • The finding that our approach to language design and tool implementation, using standard client-side browser tools (HTML5 and JavaScript), was particularly amenable to augmenting the tool with accessibility features;

  • Ceptre supports domain-specific sub-language development for common puzzle game implementation features.


Broader Impacts

The project supported initial research projects for three Ph.D. students, a research experience for one masters student, and REU opportunities for three undergraduate students of underrepresented identity in computing.


The project supported interdisciplinary bridge-building across programming languages, human-computer interaction, and computer science education by establishing the viability of applications commonly used in computer science education (puzzle game development) with Ceptre. The project also showed promise for supporting interdisciplinary research communication, based on discussions and demonstrations with a systems biology laboratory. However, further research is needed to establish the viability of this direction. 


Our website and papers demonstrate our commitment to public access to this research. The website includes tutorials, language documentation, and educational materials designed to facilitate our long-term education and outreach goals. Additional outreach was achieved by conducting a workshop and giving a talk on Ceptre at two regional community game design conferences.
